1️⃣ Wet your hands with clean water ; apply soap.
2️⃣ Lather. Lather. Lather.
3️⃣ Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
4️⃣ Rinse well.
5️⃣ Dry with a clean towel.

2⃣ Lather. Lather. Lather.
3⃣ Scrub for at least 20 seconds.
4⃣ Rinse well.
5⃣ Dry with a clean towel.

Effective handwashing is a practical skill that you can easily learn, teach to others, and practice every day. Clean hands keep you healthy and can stop germs from spreading to others. Here's what you need to know about handwashing:

3 everyday precautions you can take to help :
🧼 Wash your hands often with soap ; water
🧽 Clean ; disinfect surfaces ; objects
🗑️ Cover your cough or sneeze with a tissue then throw the tissue out

More info:

Washing your hands often will help protect you from germs, including viruses like  and . 

Not near running water? Use an alcohol-based hand rub. 

Learn more:
4. Clean your hands. Washing your hands often will help protect you from germs. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand rub.
3. Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing.  and other respiratory illnesses like RSV and whooping cough are spread by cough, sneezing, or unclean hands.

Caring for someone who has ? 

1. Avoid being face to face with the sick person. 
2. When holding sick children, place their chin on your shoulder so they don't cough in your face.
3. Wash your hands often and right away, including after handling their tissues or laundry.

Q. How should I store my cloth face covering? 

A. Face coverings should NOT be placed in pockets for later use. When storing face coverings, fold them so the contaminated outer side is folded inward, and place in a clean or new paper bag. Wash or sanitize your hands immediately.

Q. How do I safely remove my cloth face covering? 

A. Remove your face covering carefully and do not touch your eyes, nose, and mouth. Wash your hands immediately.

CHECK YOUR HAND SANITIZER: The FDA advises consumers not to use over 100 different hand sanitizers made by more than 20 companies.

Check the label on your hand sanitizer and see if the manufacturer’s name is listed.

HAND SANITIZER WARNING

Some hand sanitizers that are made in Mexico have been found to contain methanol (wood alcohol). Methanol can cause serious health problems such as blindness, and even death.

If the manufacturer’s name is on this list, stop using it immediately.

We continue to warn consumers and health care professionals not to use certain alcohol-based hand sanitizers due to the dangerous presence of methanol. To help prevent these hand sanitizers from entering the U.S., we’ve placed them on an import alert.

FDA has taken further action to help prevent these hand sanitizers from entering the U.S.  by placing them on an import alert, and we’re working with manufacturers to recall products ; encouraging retailers to remove products from store shelves ; online marketplaces.

We continue to warn consumers ; health care professionals not to use hand sanitizers with dangerous methanol (wood alcohol), which is often used in fuel ;  antifreeze. Methanol can be toxic when absorbed through the skin, ; life-threatening when ingested.

Do you know the correct way to use hand sanitizers? We encourage you to take the hand sanitizer quiz we just posted and get answers to some of the most frequently asked questions.

We have seen an increase in hand sanitizer products labeled as containing ethanol that tested positive for methanol contamination. Methanol isn't acceptable for hand sanitizers ; can be toxic when absorbed through the skin and life-threatening if ingested.

We have seen an increase in hand sanitizer products labeled to contain ethanol (ethyl alcohol) but that have tested positive for methanol. Methanol is often used to make fuel ; antifreeze; it’s not an acceptable active ingredient for hand sanitizers.

Consumer and health care personnel safety is a top priority for FDA. We’re working with industry to increase access to hand sanitizers and ensure that harmful levels of impurities are not present in ethanol used in these products.
FDA is addressing safety concerns about alcohol-based hand sanitizers, including ingestion by children, while continuing to ensure availability of these products during the  pandemic.

. In total, we received only about a third of what we requested. The number of basic surgical and face masks we received exceeded our request, and the number of gloves came close to what we asked - but for all other items, we received far less than we requested.

. With three shipments received from the stockpile, we have received these portions of requested items: 48% of N95 masks, 119% of surgical face masks, 23% of face shields, 18% of gowns, 92% of gloves. We have not received any bouffants, shoe covers or goggles.

. This morning we received our second allocation of PPE from the federal Strategic National Stockpile. The shipment was delivered to our warehouse on 5 trucks and included N-95 respirators, surgical masks, face shields, surgical gowns and gloves.

We are warning people about certain hand sanitizer products, including those manufactured by Harmonic Nature S de RL de MI in Mexico, that are labeled to contain ethanol or isopropyl alcohol but have tested positive for 1-propanol contamination.
FDA issued a warning letter to Soluciones Cosmetics, SA de CV for Bersih hand sanitizers, that are labeled to contain ethanol but tested positive for methanol contamination.

To help ensure hand sanitizers produced under our temporary guidances do not have unsafe methanol levels, we clarified that companies test each lot of the active ingredient (ethanol or isopropyl alcohol) for methanol, if obtained from another source.
FDA continues to help protect public health during . Read about our latest activities regarding fraudulent products; hand sanitizers; and testing.

We continue to warn consumers and health care professionals not to use certain alcohol-based hand sanitizers due to the dangerous presence of methanol. To help prevent these hand sanitizers from entering the U.S., we’ve placed them on an import alert.

We continue to see rising cases of adverse events, including blindness, cardiac effects, effects on the central nervous system, and hospitalizations and death. FDA has a do-not-use list of dangerous hand sanitizer products, which is updated regularly.

FDA has taken further action to help prevent these hand sanitizers from entering the U.S.  by placing them on an import alert, and we’re working with manufacturers to recall products ; encouraging retailers to remove products from store shelves ; online marketplaces.

We continue to warn consumers ; health care professionals not to use hand sanitizers with dangerous methanol (wood alcohol), which is often used in fuel ;  antifreeze. Methanol can be toxic when absorbed through the skin, ; life-threatening when ingested.
FDA’s MedWatch Alert webpage on safety and reported adverse events has information on the latest recalls of several hand sanitizers because of potential methanol contamination.

We're alerting consumers ; health care professionals that additional hand sanitizer products have been added to our list of products with confirmed ; potential methanol contamination. Check your hand sanitizer product to determine if it's on this list.

We have seen an increase in hand sanitizer products labeled as containing ethanol that tested positive for methanol contamination. Methanol isn't acceptable for hand sanitizers ; can be toxic when absorbed through the skin and life-threatening if ingested.

We warned consumers and health care professionals about hand sanitizer products that contain methanol (wood alcohol), which is often used in fuel and antifreeze, as part of continued action to protect the American public.
State officials have also reported recent cases of blindness, hospitalizations and death from adults ; children ingesting hand sanitizer products contaminated with methanol.

Q: How do I clean fruits and vegetables during ?

A: 
• Do NOT wash produce with soap, disinfectant, or any other chemical.
• Rinse fruits and vegetables under cold, running tap water.
• Scrub uncut firm produce with a clean brush.

4. Clean your hands. Washing your hands often will help protect you from germs. If soap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand rub.
3. Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when coughing or sneezing.  and other respiratory illnesses like RSV and whooping cough are spread by cough, sneezing, or unclean hands.

Caring for someone who has ? 

1. Avoid being face to face with the sick person. 
2. When holding sick children, place their chin on your shoulder so they don't cough in your face.
3. Wash your hands often and right away, including after handling their tissues or laundry.

Q. How should I store my cloth face covering? 

A. Face coverings should NOT be placed in pockets for later use. When storing face coverings, fold them so the contaminated outer side is folded inward, and place in a clean or new paper bag. Wash or sanitize your hands immediately.

Q. How do I safely remove my cloth face covering? 

A. Remove your face covering carefully and do not touch your eyes, nose, and mouth. Wash your hands immediately.

Caring for someone who has ? 

1. Avoid being face to face with the sick person. 
2. When holding sick children, place their chin on your shoulder so they don't cough in your face.
3. Wash your hands often and right away, including after handling their tissues or laundry.

Q. How should I store my cloth face covering? 

A. Face coverings should NOT be placed in pockets for later use. When storing face coverings, fold them so the contaminated outer side is folded inward, and place in a clean or new paper bag. Wash or sanitize your hands immediately.

Q. How do I safely remove my cloth face covering? 

A. Remove your face covering carefully and do not touch your eyes, nose, and mouth. Wash your hands immediately.  

More:

How to care for your face covering  

Q 2: How can I sterilize/clean a cloth face covering?     

A 2: Machine wash or hand wash in hot water and regular laundry detergent.   

More:

How to care for your face covering 

Q 1: How often should I wash my face covering?   

A 1: Wash it frequently. The best thing to do is to wash it each day you use it.

Q. How should I store my cloth face covering? 

A. Face coverings should NOT be placed in pockets for later use. When storing face coverings, fold them so the contaminated outer side is folded inward, and place in a clean or new paper bag. Wash or sanitize your hands immediately.

Q. How do I safely remove my cloth face covering? 

A. Remove your face covering carefully and do not touch your eyes, nose, and mouth. Wash your hands immediately.

The soap you use does not have to be antibacterial! Any soap will protect you if you wash your hands properly. COVID-19, like many other viruses, is held together by a lipid (fatty) membrane. Washing with soap removes the fat that sits around the virus particles and destroys it.
